[I hate admitting this out loud.] (hesitantly) I suppose I am a thief.
[I need to see the gold to be sure this is worth it.] Do you have my dragon?
[I won't be cheated.] (insistently) Give it here. I want to see.
[This has gone far enough. I need to take control.] (nervously) This is far enough. There's no one about. We'll do it here.
[It's so close now. I can almost feel it.] I want my dragon.
[I can't believe I'm actually doing this.] (grabs the coin and bites it) If truth be told, I wasn't sure what gold

Pate.profile:
Pate is a novice at the Citadel in Oldtown, where he has spent five years struggling to earn even a single link in his quest to become a maester. His character embodies the conflict between youthful ambition and the harsh realities of a world that often crushes dreams. Physically unremarkable, Pate's most defining features are his naivety and his unfulfilled aspirations.

Torn between his academic pursuits and his infatuation with Rosey, a serving girl at the Quill and Tankard tavern, Pate's motivations are a mix of intellectual curiosity and base desires. His longing for Rosey leads him to make a fateful decision that sets him on a dangerous path, highlighting his vulnerability to manipulation.

Pate's key involvement in the plot revolves around his theft of Archmaester Walgrave's key, which he agrees to exchange with a mysterious alchemist for a gold dragon. This act of desperation reveals Pate's willingness to compromise his principles for a chance at love and acceptance, as well as his naivety in dealing with more cunning individuals.

Throughout his interactions with the alchemist, Pate displays a mix of anxiety, guilt, and determination. His internal struggle between his conscience and his desires is palpable, showcasing the complexity of his character despite his apparent simplicity. Pate's journey from an aspiring maester to a self-proclaimed thief marks a significant, if tragic, arc in his development.

Pate's story serves as a lens through which readers glimpse the intricate world of the Citadel, including its politics, mysteries, and the challenges faced by those seeking knowledge and advancement within its walls. His experiences with the alchemist also introduce elements of intrigue and danger that extend beyond the academic realm, hinting at larger conspiracies and the presence of powerful, shadowy figures operating in Oldtown.

conversations.name: Peck
conversations.thought: Lord Jaime intimidates me, but I respect him deeply. I'm nervous about his presence and unsure how to act. Pia's beauty has caught my eye, but I don't know how to approach her. I hope I don't embarrass myself in front of my lord. I want to prove my worth as a squire.

utterances.message: [I can't believe Lord Jaime is asking me this. What should I say?] (turns beet red)
[I'm both excited and nervous about this opportunity.] (stammers) Kind, my lord? How... how would I...?
[This is all happening so fast. I need to know more.] My lord, I... where should I take her? There's never a place to... to...
[I can't believe he's suggesting we use Lord Lancel's bed!] (eyes widen) His lordship's bed?

Peck.profile:
Peck is a young squire in service to Jaime Lannister during the events of "A Feast for Crows". Though not a major character, Peck's interactions with Jaime provide insight into both characters and the social dynamics of Westeros. Peck is characterized by his youth, inexperience, and innocence, particularly in matters of romance and sexuality. His bashful nature is evident in his interactions with Jaime, often blushing and stammering when discussing personal matters.

As a squire, Peck is dutiful and respectful towards his lord, Jaime Lannister. He shows a mix of awe and intimidation in Jaime's presence, indicative of the power dynamics between knights and their squires in the feudal society of Westeros. Peck's desire to prove his worth as a squire is apparent, though he often struggles with his nervousness and uncertainty.

Peck's character serves to highlight Jaime's more experienced and worldly nature. Through their interactions, we see Jaime taking on a mentorship role, offering advice on matters beyond mere knightly duties. This is particularly evident in Jaime's guidance regarding Peck's attraction to Pia, a serving girl at Castle Darry. Jaime's frank and somewhat mischievous advice about pursuing Pia reveals both Peck's innocence and Jaime's more cynical view of relationships and power.

While Peck's overall arc in the story is limited, his presence adds depth to the cast of characters surrounding Jaime Lannister and provides a lens through which to view the complexities of Westerosi society and the realities of life for young men in service to powerful lords.

plots.name: Petyr Baelish
plots.description: Lord Protector of the Vale, posing as Sansa's father.
plots.summary: Petyr orchestrates the cover-up of Lysa's murder, manipulating the situation to maintain his power and protect Sansa. He skillfully manages the visiting nobles and the false confession of Marillion.

plots.name: Petyr Baelish
plots.description: Lord Protector of the Vale, posing as Alayne's father.
plots.summary: Instructs Alayne on how to handle the Lords Declarant's visit and discusses political strategy with her.

conversations.name: Petyr Baelish
conversations.thought: Everything hinges on this moment. Sansa's performance must be flawless to secure our position. I must appear as the grieving widower while orchestrating this elaborate deception. The Vale nobles are suspicious, but they lack proof. Marillion's false confession is our safety net. I must guide this interrogation to our advantage.

utterances.message: [Sansa is doing well, but I must support her story.] It's alright, sweetling. Take your time. (to Lord Nestor) Forgive her, my lords. She still has nightmares of that day.
[I must appear grief-stricken yet composed.] I had just left the room. If I had known... (shakes his head) I will never forgive myself for not being there to protect her.
[Everything is going according to plan.] As you wish, my lord. Mord, take him back to his sky cell.

Petyr Baelish.profile:
Petyr Baelish, also known as Littlefinger, is a masterful manipulator and one of the most cunning players in the game of thrones. As the newly appointed Lord Protector of the Vale, he continues to weave his intricate web of deceit and political maneuvering in "A Feast for Crows."

Baelish's background as a minor lord has shaped his relentless ambition and his skill in using secrets and manipulation to climb the ladder of power. His physical appearance is often described as unremarkable, with a slim build and sharp features, but it's his quick wit and silver tongue that truly define him.

In this installment, Baelish's core motivations revolve around consolidating his power in the Vale and protecting Sansa Stark, whom he has disguised as his illegitimate daughter, Alayne Stone. His affection for Sansa, rooted in his past love for her mother Catelyn, adds a complex layer to his character.

Baelish's most notable attribute is his ability to orchestrate elaborate schemes. This is evident in his masterful cover-up of Lysa Arryn's murder, which he himself committed. He skillfully manages the aftermath, manipulating both Sansa and the Vale nobles to maintain his position and avoid suspicion.

His relationship with Sansa is pivotal to the plot, as he acts as both protector and mentor, teaching her the intricacies of political maneuvering. However, this relationship is fraught with moral ambiguity, given Sansa's youth and Baelish's ulterior motives.

Throughout the story, Baelish demonstrates his political acumen by deftly handling the investigation into Lysa's death, coaching Sansa on her role in the deception, and preparing for the arrival of the Lords Declarant. His actions consistently reveal his primary goal: to accumulate more power while keeping his true intentions hidden.

Petyr Baelish remains a central figure in the unfolding drama of the Seven Kingdoms, his every move calculated to advance his position in the ever-shifting landscape of power.

plots.name: Pia
plots.description: A serving girl from Harrenhal, now accompanying Jaime's group.
plots.summary: Pia's presence reminds Jaime of past events and temptations. He arranges for his squire Peck to spend time with her, showing a mix of pragmatism and concern for both of them.

utterances.message: [I'm disappointed to leave, but I must obey.] (covers her mouth) Aye, m'lord. Thank you, m'lord.

Pia.profile:
Pia is a serving girl from Harrenhal who appears in "A Feast for Crows," the fourth book in George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. Her character, though minor, provides insight into the harsh realities faced by common folk in times of war and serves as a catalyst for character development in others.

Physically, Pia is described as attractive enough to catch the eye of young men, including Jaime Lannister's squire, Peck. However, her most notable feature is her broken teeth, a painful reminder of the brutality she has endured. This injury affects her speech, causing her to cover her mouth when speaking.

Pia's experiences have shaped her into a survivor in a cruel world. Despite the hardships she has faced, including likely sexual abuse during the war, she maintains a certain resilience. Her presence in Jaime's entourage suggests she has found a measure of protection by aligning herself with the Lannister forces.

In terms of personality, Pia is obedient and cautious, quickly following orders from those in power. Her interactions with Jaime demonstrate a mix of deference and gratitude, indicating she understands the precarious nature of her position and the importance of staying in favor with those who can protect her.

Pia's role in the story is primarily to illuminate the character of others, particularly Jaime Lannister. His treatment of her, arranging for her to spend time with his squire Peck, reveals a complex mix of pragmatism and a degree of consideration for those under his command. This interaction showcases Jaime's evolving character, as he navigates his role as a leader and mentor while reflecting on his own past experiences and temptations.

While Pia's direct impact on the main plot may be limited, her presence serves as a poignant reminder of the human cost of the wars and political machinations that drive the larger narrative of "A Song of Ice and Fire."

plots.name: Podrick Payne
plots.description: Brienne's young squire, loyal but inexperienced.
plots.summary: Podrick shows his loyalty to Brienne by agreeing to watch over her while she sleeps and attempting to protect their belongings from Crabb.

plots.name: Podrick Payne
plots.description: Brienne's young squire accompanying her on her quest.
plots.summary: Podrick remains loyal to Brienne, offering suggestions and support as they search for lodging and continue their journey.

conversations.name: Podrick Payne
conversations.thought: I'm eager to prove my worth to Lady Brienne, but I'm uncertain about my abilities. The responsibility of watching over her while she sleeps is daunting, yet I'm determined not to let her down. I'm nervous about the potential threats, especially from Crabb, but I want to show Lady Brienne that I can be relied upon. I must stay alert and follow her instructions precisely.

conversations.name: Podrick Payne
conversations.thought: I'm loyal to Lady Brienne and want to support her, but I'm increasingly worried about our safety and the difficulties we face. I'm exhausted from our travels and encounters. Part of me wishes we could find an easier path, maybe even return home, but I don't want to disappoint Lady Brienne. I'm hoping we can find comfortable lodging for the night, but I'm prepared for any hardship.

utterances.message: [I'm nervous about this responsibility, but I want to help.] Stay awake, my lady? Ser. (hesitates) I have a sword. If Crabb tries to hurt you, I could kill him.
[I'm relieved I don't have to fight, but still nervous about the responsibility.] Yes, my lady. Ser. I'll watch carefully.
[I feel a bit more confident now.] Thank you, my lady. I won't let you down.
[I'm trying to memorize her instructions.] Wake you immediately. Don't confront. I understand.
[I'm grateful for her concern.] Yes, my lady. I'll rest when you're awake. Thank you for looking out for me too.
[I'm concerned about our safety, but I don't want to disappoint Lady Brienne.] Ser? My lady? What if my lady did go home? My other lady, I mean. Ser. Lady Sansa.
[I need to find a way to convince her.] Still. That's where her gods are. And gods can't die.
[I'm worried, but I trust Lady Brienne's judgment.] Yes, my lady. Where shall we go now?
[I hope we find somewhere comfortable.] Do you think they'll have real beds, my lady?
[I'm tired, but I won't complain.] I don't mind, my lady. I can sleep anywhere.
[I'm curious about this place, but I shouldn't speak out of turn.] (looks around the room with wide eyes)

Podrick Payne.profile:
Podrick Payne is a young, loyal squire who accompanies Brienne of Tarth on her quest to find Sansa Stark in "A Feast for Crows." Despite his inexperience and youth, Podrick demonstrates unwavering dedication to Brienne, often referred to as "my lady" or "ser" due to her unusual status as a female knight.

Podrick's character is defined by his eagerness to please and prove his worth, coupled with a touch of naivety that stems from his youth. He shows a willingness to take on responsibilities beyond his years, such as offering to watch over Brienne while she sleeps and protect their belongings from potential threats. His loyalty is evident in his readiness to follow Brienne's instructions and his concern for her well-being.

Throughout their journey, Podrick faces numerous challenges and hardships, from treacherous terrain to encounters with dangerous individuals. He adapts to these difficulties with a mix of trepidation and determination, always striving to support Brienne in her mission. His character develops as he gains more experience, learning to navigate the complex and often perilous world they traverse.

Podrick's relationship with Brienne is central to his character arc. He looks up to her as a mentor and protector, while she, in turn, takes care to instruct and safeguard him. Their dynamic is one of mutual support and growing trust, with Podrick's innocence often providing a contrast to the harsh realities they face.

As they continue their search for Sansa Stark, Podrick's resilience shines through. He adapts to difficult sleeping arrangements, endures long travels, and faces dangerous situations with a quiet determination. His suggestions, such as considering the possibility of Sansa returning to her home, reveal a thoughtful side to his character, even if his ideas are sometimes colored by his youthful perspective.

Podrick Payne emerges as a steadfast companion in Brienne's quest, his loyalty and growth serving as a testament to the bond forged between knight and squire in the face of adversity.

plots.name: Qyburn
plots.description: Former maester, now serving Cersei.
plots.summary: Qyburn is appointed to care for Gregor Clegane and investigate Tyrion's escape, gaining Cersei's trust.

plots.name: Qyburn
plots.description: A disgraced former maester, now serving as Cersei's advisor and spymaster.
plots.summary: Qyburn has taken Varys' place as the master of whispers. He's loyal to Cersei, providing her with information and carrying out her tasks, including the preparation of Gregor Clegane's skull.

plots.name: Qyburn
plots.description: Cersei's confidant and former maester
plots.summary: Qyburn discusses secret plans with Cersei, including the creation of a mysterious new champion.

conversations.name: Qyburn
conversations.thought: I observe the Queen's subtle reactions, ready to provide whatever support she requires. This moment could significantly impact her stability and our plans. I must remain vigilant, analyzing both the alleged evidence and Cersei's response to it. My role is crucial in maintaining her trust and furthering our shared objectives.

Qyburn.profile:
Qyburn is a complex and morally ambiguous character in "A Feast for Crows," the fourth installment of George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A disgraced former maester, Qyburn has found new purpose and power as a trusted advisor to Queen Cersei Lannister. His fall from the Citadel, likely due to unethical practices, has not dampened his intellect or ambition, but rather redirected them towards more clandestine and questionable pursuits.

Physically nondescript, Qyburn's true strength lies in his keen mind and willingness to push the boundaries of conventional knowledge and ethics. He possesses a vast array of skills, from healing to espionage, making him an invaluable asset to those who can stomach his methods. His appointment to the Small Council as the new Master of Whisperers, replacing the enigmatic Varys, demonstrates both his rising influence and Cersei's trust in his abilities.

Qyburn's loyalty to Cersei is a defining aspect of his character in this book. He serves her diligently, overseeing delicate matters such as the search for the fugitive Tyrion Lannister and the preparation of Gregor Clegane's skull for diplomatic purposes. His willingness to engage in morally questionable tasks without hesitation aligns well with Cersei's increasingly paranoid and ruthless approach to power.

Throughout the narrative, Qyburn's character serves as a reflection of the changing political landscape in King's Landing. His rise to prominence symbolizes the decay of traditional institutions and the ascendance of more pragmatic, if unsavory, methods of maintaining power. As he continues to prove his worth to Cersei, Qyburn's influence grows, setting the stage for potentially far-reaching consequences in the realm's future.

plots.name: Ronnet Connington
plots.description: A knight from House Connington, formerly betrothed to Brienne.
plots.summary: Ronnet encounters Jaime at the bear pit and reveals his past connection to Brienne, showing disdain for her appearance and character.

conversations.name: Ronnet Connington
conversations.thought: Connington revels in the opportunity to belittle Brienne and assert his perceived superiority. He's eager to share his past connection to her, taking pleasure in mocking her appearance and character. Beneath his bravado, he harbors a desire to impress Jaime Lannister, conscious of their differing social statuses and family legacies.

utterances.message: [I relish the chance to mock Brienne.] (Raising his lantern) I wished to see where the bear danced with the maiden not-so-fair. Is it true the wench fought naked?
[I can't resist another jab at Brienne's appearance.] (Laughing) ...the sight of Brienne naked might have made the bear flee in terror.
[I take pride in revealing this information.] I was betrothed to her.
[I enjoy recounting this story.] Thrice. I was the second. My father's notion. I had heard the wench was ugly, and I told him so, but he said all women were the same once you blew the candle out.
[I clarify the family relation, somewhat proud of the connection.] Cousin. Lord Jon had no brothers.

Ronnet Connington.profile:
Ser Ronnet Connington, also known as Red Ronnet, is a knight from House Connington, a noble family with historical ties to the Targaryens. Ronnet is a distant cousin of the late Jon Connington, who served as Hand of the King to Aerys II Targaryen. This connection to a once-powerful house likely influences Ronnet's sense of pride and entitlement.

Physically, Ronnet is notable for his red hair, which likely contributes to his nickname. His personality is marked by a cruel streak and a penchant for mockery, particularly evident in his treatment of Brienne of Tarth. Ronnet was once betrothed to Brienne, a match arranged by his father, but he rejected her based on her appearance, demonstrating his shallow nature and adherence to conventional standards of beauty.

Ronnet's encounter with Jaime Lannister at Harrenhal's bear pit reveals much about his character. He shows no remorse or empathy when discussing Brienne's ordeal in the pit, instead using it as an opportunity to further demean her. His eagerness to share the story of his broken betrothal to Brienne with Jaime suggests a desire to impress those he perceives as socially superior, while simultaneously boosting his own ego at Brienne's expense.

Throughout the narrative, Ronnet serves as a foil to characters like Jaime and Brienne, highlighting their growth and honorable qualities in contrast to his own static, derisive nature. His presence in the story underscores themes of chivalry, honor, and the often cruel nature of Westerosi society, particularly towards those who don't conform to its norms.

plots.name: Robert Arryn
plots.description: The young, sickly Lord of the Eyrie.
plots.summary: Robert is traumatized by his mother's death and suffers from seizures. He depends on Sansa for comfort and care, adding to her emotional burden.

plots.name: Robert Arryn
plots.description: Young Lord of the Eyrie, sickly and prone to fits.
plots.summary: Has a tantrum during breakfast, highlighting the precarious situation in the Vale.

Robert Arryn.profile:
Robert Arryn, the young Lord of the Eyrie, is a fragile and sickly child thrust into a position of power following his mother's tragic death. As the sole heir to House Arryn, Robert's precarious health and emotional instability play a significant role in the political landscape of the Vale. Physically weak and prone to seizures, he embodies the vulnerability of childhood amidst the harsh realities of Westeros.

Robert's character is defined by his dependency on others, particularly his attachment to Sansa Stark (disguised as Alayne Stone), who becomes a source of comfort and care in the wake of his mother's passing. His frequent tantrums and fits highlight the challenges faced by those around him, including Petyr Baelish and the nobles of the Vale, as they attempt to navigate the complex politics of the region while managing a child lord.

The trauma of losing his mother, Lysa Arryn, has left a deep impact on Robert's already fragile psyche. This event, coupled with the false accusation against Marillion for Lysa's murder, adds layers of complexity to the young lord's situation and the overall plot surrounding the Eyrie.

Robert's presence in the story serves as a catalyst for various political machinations and highlights the precarious balance of power in the Vale. His condition and behavior during key moments, such as his tantrum during the breakfast before the arrival of the Lords Declarant, underscore the challenges faced by those attempting to maintain stability in the region.

As the story progresses, Robert Arryn remains a central figure in the Vale's storyline, his health and well-being intertwined with the fates of characters like Sansa and Petyr Baelish. His vulnerability and the responsibility placed upon him as Lord of the Eyrie make him a pivotal character in the unfolding drama of Westeros.

plots.name: Rodrik Harlaw
plots.description: Asha's uncle, Lord of Harlaw, known as the Reader.
plots.summary: Rodrik warns Asha against attending the kingsmoot, advising her to stay with her mother. He offers her Ten Towers as inheritance but fails to dissuade her from pursuing the Seastone Chair.

conversations.name: Rodrik Harlaw
conversations.thought: I fear for Asha's safety and future. This kingsmoot is a dangerous gamble that could lead to bloodshed. I must convince her to abandon this foolish quest and stay safe. Perhaps offering her Ten Towers will sway her. I worry about my sister Lanny, who has already lost so much. Asha's ambition may cost her everything.

utterances.message: [I must try to reason with her.] Asha, you come too late. Aeron Damphair has called a kingsmoot on Old Wyk.
[She doesn't understand the danger.] The Damphair has not japed since he was drowned. This is serious, Asha. You should not go to Old Wyk.
[Her enthusiasm worries me.] Four thousand years, if Haereg can be believed. Asha, you will not be chosen. No woman has ever ruled the ironborn.
[I must make her see reason.] You are still a willful child. Think of your poor mother. You are all that Lanny has left to her.
[A final attempt to protect her.] Stay, and I shall name you heir to the Ten Towers. Be content with that.
[I've failed to convince her.] (sighs) Then you are just another crow, screaming for carrion. Go. I wish to return to Archmaester Marwyn and his search.

Rodrik Harlaw.profile:
Rodrik Harlaw, known as "the Reader," is the Lord of Harlaw and a prominent figure in the Iron Islands. Unlike many of his fellow Ironborn, Rodrik is a scholarly man with a passion for books and learning, as evidenced by his vast library at Ten Towers. His nickname stems from his unusual predilection for reading in a culture that traditionally values martial prowess over intellectual pursuits.

As Asha Greyjoy's uncle, Rodrik plays a significant role in her storyline during the tumultuous period following Balon Greyjoy's death. He is a voice of reason and caution in the face of the impending kingsmoot, an ancient method of choosing a new king that hasn't been used in four thousand years. Rodrik's character embodies a more measured and thoughtful approach to leadership, contrasting sharply with the typically aggressive and war-hungry attitudes of many Ironborn.

Rodrik's relationship with Asha is complex, marked by genuine care and concern for her well-being. He attempts to dissuade her from attending the kingsmoot, warning her of the dangers and offering her Ten Towers as an inheritance instead. This gesture demonstrates both his affection for his niece and his pragmatic nature, recognizing the challenges she faces as a woman vying for leadership in the patriarchal Ironborn society.

Despite his wisdom and foresight, Rodrik's influence is limited by the deeply ingrained traditions and expectations of his culture. His preference for books over battle and his attempts to steer Asha away from the kingsmoot reflect his understanding of the political landscape and the potential for bloodshed. However, his inability to convince Asha highlights the strong currents of ambition and tradition that shape the Iron Islands' politics.

Rodrik Harlaw stands out as a unique character in the Iron Islands, embodying a different kind of strength – one based on knowledge and foresight rather than physical might. His presence adds depth to the portrayal of Ironborn culture and provides a counterpoint to the more stereotypical depictions of their society.

plots.name: Samwell Tarly
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, tasked with escorting Maester Aemon and Gilly to Oldtown.
plots.summary: Sam struggles with seasickness and fear while trying to care for his companions during the difficult voyage. He attempts to comfort Gilly and protect Maester Aemon, all while grappling with his own insecurities.

plots.name: Samwell Tarly
plots.description: A brother of the Night's Watch, trying to care for his companions in Braavos.
plots.summary: Sam is struggling with the responsibility of caring for Maester Aemon and Gilly while dealing with limited resources and Dareon's abandonment. He feels fear and inadequacy but tries to manage their situation.

conversations.name: Samwell Tarly
conversations.thought: I'm overwhelmed by seasickness and the responsibility of caring for everyone. Gilly's constant crying worries me deeply, and I fear for Maester Aemon's health. I must find a way to comfort Gilly and ensure everyone's safety on this perilous voyage. Perhaps Maester Aemon can offer some wisdom or remedy to ease our troubles.

conversations.name: Samwell Tarly
conversations.thought: I'm overwhelmed with worry for Maester Aemon's deteriorating health and our precarious situation. We're running out of money and supplies, and I feel utterly alone in this foreign city. I must find a way to get us to Oldtown safely, but how? I'm terrified of failing, yet I know I must stay strong for everyone's sake. I need to convince Aemon to eat and rest, while also planning our next move.

utterances.message: [I must find a way to comfort Gilly. Her constant crying is worrying.] Gilly, please don't cry. We're going to a safe place. A warm place.
[Her distress is affecting everyone. Maybe Maester Aemon can help.] Isn't there something you can give her? Some herb or potion, so she won't be so afraid?
[I don't understand. Why would she be grieving?] She's going to a safe place. A warm place. Why should she be grieving?
[Confusion and disbelief wash over me.] He's greensick, that's all. We're all greensick. Once we make port in Braavos...
[The realization hits me like a physical blow.] That couldn't... she wouldn't... of course he's hers. Gilly would never have left the Wall without her son. She loves him.
[I feel a mix of shock and betrayal.] No. No, that's wrong. Jon would never...
[My heart aches seeing him so confused. I must be patient.] It's me, Samwell Tarly. Your steward.
[I'm worried about his fever.] (Feeling Aemon's brow) No. It's night, maester. You've been asleep.
[I feel guilty for not being able to provide better care.] We have no wood, and the innkeep will not give us more unless we have the coin.
[I need to protect him from overexertion.] You're too weak to go out. On the morrow we can go to the docks. You can ask about and find which ship is departing next for Oldtown.
[I'm concerned about his lack of appetite.] Are you hungry, maester? We have some bread left, and a bit of cheese.
[I must find a way to nourish him.] How will you get stronger unless you eat? Perhaps a sip of wine, though?

Samwell Tarly.profile:
Samwell Tarly, a brother of the Night's Watch, is a complex character whose journey in "A Feast for Crows" is marked by personal growth and challenges. Physically unimposing and prone to seasickness, Sam's true strength lies in his intellect, compassion, and unwavering loyalty. Initially lacking confidence, he is thrust into a position of responsibility when tasked with escorting Maester Aemon, Gilly, and her baby from the Wall to Oldtown.

Sam's character is defined by his kindness and desire to care for others, often putting their needs before his own. This is evident in his tireless efforts to comfort the grieving Gilly and tend to the ailing Maester Aemon during their perilous sea voyage and subsequent stay in Braavos. Despite his own fears and insecurities, Sam demonstrates remarkable resilience and adaptability in the face of adversity.

Throughout the story, Sam grapples with the weight of his responsibilities and the harsh realities of the world. His naivety is gradually replaced by a growing understanding of complex situations, as seen in his dawning realization of Gilly's true grief over leaving her child behind. This emotional intelligence, coupled with his academic inclinations, makes him a valuable ally and caretaker for the elderly Maester Aemon.

Sam's journey is fraught with challenges, including limited resources, abandonment by companions, and the constant struggle to find safe passage to Oldtown. These trials force him to confront his fears and push beyond his perceived limitations, driving his character development. His dedication to his mission and his companions, despite overwhelming odds, showcases his inner strength and loyalty to the Night's Watch.

In essence, Samwell Tarly emerges as a character who, despite his outward appearance and self-doubt, possesses a quiet strength and determination. His arc in "A Feast for Crows" is one of resilience in the face of adversity, growing wisdom, and unwavering commitment to his duties and those under his care.

plots.name: Sansa Stark
plots.description: A young girl posing as Alayne Stone, Petyr Baelish's natural daughter.
plots.summary: Sansa struggles with the lies she must tell about Lysa's death, balancing her fear and guilt with the need for self-preservation. She cares for Robert Arryn while navigating the dangerous political situation.

plots.name: Sansa Stark
plots.description: Disguised as Alayne Stone, Littlefinger's bastard daughter.
plots.summary: Prepares for the Lords Declarant's arrival, maintains her disguise, and navigates the tense political situation at the Eyrie.

conversations.name: Sansa Stark
conversations.thought: My heart pounds with fear and guilt. I must remember every detail of our fabricated story. One misstep could doom Petyr and me. I feel the weight of my lies, the eyes of the lords upon me. I must appear traumatized yet coherent, a delicate balance to maintain. Lord Robert's fragile state adds to my burden.

conversations.name: Sansa Stark
conversations.thought: My heart races beneath my carefully chosen dress. I must embody Alayne Stone completely, suppressing any hint of Sansa Stark. Lord Royce's presence terrifies me; his recognition could shatter everything. I need to be the perfect hostess, diplomatic yet unremarkable. Father's lessons echo in my mind: observe, learn, and above all, keep our secrets. The weight of the Vale's future rests on this meeting's outcome.

utterances.message: [I must appear distraught but coherent.] (takes a shaky breath) It... it was horrible, my lord. I was with Lady Lysa when... (pauses, as if overcome)
[I must continue, no matter how much it pains me.] (nods and wipes a tear) When Marillion... pushed her. (continues with the rehearsed story)
[I must sound convincing.] (nods vigorously) Yes, my lord. I saw it with my own eyes. It was terrible.
[His lies protect me, but at what cost?] (looks away, feeling a mixture of guilt and relief)
[I'm nervous but must appear confident.] Lord Royce, will you have a cup of wine, to take the chill off?
[My heart is racing. I must not give myself away.] (She remains silent, feeling as though she had swallowed her tongue)
[I must remember Alayne's age, not my own.] Four-fourteen, my lady. And I am no child, but a maiden flowered.
[I feel uncomfortable and vulnerable, but I must maintain my composure.] (She remains silent, unsure how to respond to the suggestive comments)

Sansa Stark.profile:
Sansa Stark, disguised as Alayne Stone in "A Feast for Crows," is a young woman forced to navigate a treacherous political landscape while concealing her true identity. Once the daughter of Winterfell, she now poses as the natural daughter of Petyr Baelish, adapting to her new role with a mixture of fear, guilt, and determination.

Physically, Sansa is described as a maiden of fourteen, with features reminiscent of her Stark heritage that she must carefully disguise. Her appearance is meticulously cultivated to reinforce her false identity as Alayne Stone, from her choice of attire to her mannerisms.

Sansa's personality is shaped by her experiences, revealing a complex blend of vulnerability and growing resilience. She struggles with the weight of the lies she must maintain, particularly regarding Lysa Arryn's death, while simultaneously developing skills in diplomacy and observation. Her core motivations revolve around self-preservation and loyalty to those protecting her, primarily Petyr Baelish.

Throughout the story, Sansa's character arc shows her grappling with moral ambiguity as she becomes entangled in Baelish's schemes. She cares for the fragile Robert Arryn while navigating the dangerous political currents of the Vale. Her ability to maintain composure under scrutiny, such as during Lord Nestor Royce's investigation and the arrival of the Lords Declarant, demonstrates her growing adaptability and cunning.

Sansa's relationships are complex and fraught with tension. Her dependency on Petyr Baelish is evident, as is her unease with the role she must play. Her interactions with the Vale nobles, particularly the perceptive Yohn Royce, highlight the constant threat of discovery she faces.

Key experiences in this part of her journey include her involvement in covering up Lysa Arryn's murder and her role in hosting the Lords Declarant at the Eyrie. These events test her ability to maintain her facade and navigate adult political situations, often tinged with inappropriate sexual undertones that make her uncomfortable.

Sansa's development is marked by her increasing skill in playing the game of political intrigue, balanced against the psychological toll of living a lie. Her journey in "A Feast for Crows" sees her transforming from a passive pawn to a more active participant in the machinations around her, setting the stage for her potential emergence as a political player in her own right.

plots.name: Meribald
plots.description: A wandering septon guiding the group to the Quiet Isle.
plots.summary: Meribald leads the group across the mudflats, demonstrating his familiarity with the area and its customs. He introduces the group to the brothers and explains some of the isle's history.

utterances.message: [I should explain why we've come.] Thank you for your hospitality, Elder Brother. We've come seeking information about the Hound.

plots.name: Arys Oakheart
plots.description: A Kingsguard knight assigned to protect Princess Myrcella in Dorne.
plots.summary: Arys is conflicted between his Kingsguard vows and his love for Arianne Martell. He struggles with guilt over their affair and is torn about supporting Myrcella's claim to the throne.

plots.name: Arys Oakheart
plots.description: Kingsguard knight sworn to protect Myrcella, involved in a romantic relationship with Arianne.
plots.summary: Torn between his duty to protect Myrcella and his love for Arianne, he helps with the plot while providing information about events in King's Landing.

plots.name: Arys Oakheart
plots.description: Kingsguard knight sworn to protect Myrcella, involved in a romantic relationship with Arianne.
plots.summary: Dies defending Arianne and Myrcella from Areo Hotah's men, charging into battle despite being outnumbered.

conversations.name: Arys Oakheart
conversations.thought: Guilt and desire war within me. I must end this affair to honor my vows, but Arianne's allure is overpowering. I'm torn between my duty to the Kingsguard and my feelings for her. Protecting Myrcella is paramount, yet I fear I'm being pulled into dangerous political waters.

conversations.name: Arys Oakheart
conversations.thought: I'm torn between my duty and my heart. Bringing Myrcella here feels like a betrayal of my vows, but I can't resist Arianne. I must find a way to protect Myrcella while supporting this plot. The news of Tywin's death will change everything. I fear the consequences of our actions, but it's too late to turn back now.

conversations.name: Arys Oakheart
conversations.thought: My heart races with fear and determination. I've broken my vows for Arianne, but I will not fail in my duty to protect Myrcella. I love Arianne, but my honor as a Kingsguard comes first now. If this is to be my last stand, let it be a glorious one. I must buy them time to escape, even at the cost of my life.

utterances.message: [I must stay strong and end this, for my honor's sake.] My lady, I came to tell you this must end. For your sake as well as mine.
[By the Seven, she's beautiful. No, I must resist.] (looks away) I have learned too much from you already.
[I must make her understand.] You know I have no other woman. Only... duty.
[I cannot falter.] My place is at the palace.
[I must make my feelings for Myrcella clear.] You should not say such things. I love Myrcella as a daughter.
[What is she suggesting?] (frowns) The Water Gardens are no prison.
[I'm confused and conflicted.] No more than you have sworn. Protect Myrcella with your life. Defend her...
[I must speak with Arianne alone. This is madness, but I cannot stop now.] Princess, I beg a moment's word.

[I must report everything, though it pains me to betray my vows.] Little enough. Before we left King's Landing, her uncle reminded her that I was her protector and that any commands that I might give her were meant to keep her safe. She has heard them in the streets as well, shouting out for vengeance. She knew this was no game.
[This will change everything.] Tywin Lannister is dead. Murdered by the Imp. The queen has assumed the regency.
[I must fulfill my duty, even if it costs my life.] You will not take her whilst I still draw breath. (puts his horse between Arianne and the crossbows)
[I choose death with honor over life with shame.] (gives Arianne one last longing look, then charges towards the poleboat)

Arys Oakheart.profile:
Ser Arys Oakheart is a complex and ultimately tragic figure in "A Feast for Crows." As a knight of the Kingsguard, he is sworn to protect Princess Myrcella Baratheon in Dorne. Arys is characterized by his strong sense of duty and honor, which often conflicts with his personal desires and emotions.

Physically, Arys is described as a handsome and capable warrior, befitting his role as a member of the elite Kingsguard. His most defining relationship is his secret, passionate affair with Princess Arianne Martell of Dorne. This illicit romance becomes the catalyst for his internal struggle between his sworn vows of celibacy and his heart's desires.

Arys's character arc is driven by this central conflict. He is torn between his duty to protect Myrcella, his vows as a Kingsguard, and his love for Arianne. This internal turmoil is further complicated when Arianne involves him in her plot to crown Myrcella as Queen of the Seven Kingdoms, challenging the current political order.

Throughout the story, Arys grapples with guilt over breaking his vows and fears the consequences of his actions. He provides valuable information about events in King's Landing, including the death of Tywin Lannister, which Arianne uses to further her plans.

Arys's journey culminates in a moment of self-sacrifice. When Arianne's plot is discovered and thwarted by her father's men, Arys makes the ultimate choice between love and duty. In a final act of valor and redemption, he charges into battle against overwhelming odds to protect Arianne and Myrcella, knowing it will lead to his death.

Ser Arys Oakheart's story is one of a man caught between conflicting loyalties, whose choices lead him down a path of no return. His tragic end serves as a poignant reminder of the costs of duty, desire, and political intrigue in the world of "A Song of Ice and Fire."

plots.name: Bonifer Hasty
plots.description: A pious knight appointed as castellan of Harrenhal.
plots.summary: Ser Bonifer is appointed by Jaime to hold Harrenhal. He is deeply religious and aims to bring order to the castle and surrounding lands.

Bonifer Hasty.profile:
Ser Bonifer Hasty is a pious knight who plays a minor yet significant role in "A Feast for Crows." Known for his deep religious convictions, Bonifer is appointed by Jaime Lannister as the castellan of the notoriously cursed castle of Harrenhal in the aftermath of Gregor Clegane's brutal occupation. 

Bonifer's most defining characteristic is his unwavering faith, which shapes his actions and demeanor. His appointment to Harrenhal is noteworthy, as it demonstrates Jaime's intent to bring order and stability to the troubled region. As castellan, Ser Bonifer is tasked with the challenging responsibility of managing the massive, half-ruined castle and restoring peace to its surrounding lands.

While not physically described in detail, Bonifer's presence is marked by his reputation for piety and his commitment to righteous governance. His appointment to such a significant position suggests that he is respected for his integrity and capability, despite not being a major political player in the Seven Kingdoms.

Bonifer Hasty's role in the story, though brief, highlights the ongoing efforts to stabilize the realm in the wake of war and chaos. His character serves as a counterpoint to the more morally ambiguous figures that often dominate the narrative, representing an attempt to bring honor and godliness to a place long associated with darkness and tragedy.

plots.name: Daven Lannister
plots.description: Jaime's cousin, the new Warden of the West.
plots.summary: Daven provides Jaime with information about the siege and expresses frustration with the Freys. He discusses the challenges they face and his reluctance to be named Warden of the West.

conversations.name: Daven Lannister
conversations.thought: I'm relieved Jaime is here to help with this frustrating siege. The Freys are unreliable allies, and our resources are stretched thin. I hope Jaime's presence will bring a fresh perspective and perhaps a solution to our problems. I need to convey the gravity of our situation without seeming incompetent. Maybe Jaime can deal with the Freys more effectively than I have.

utterances.message: [Where to begin with this mess?] The siege drags on. The Blackfish sits inside the castle, we sit outside in our camps. Bloody boring, if you want the truth.

[I hope Jaime appreciates the challenges we face.] We have the castle well encircled. Ser Ryman and the Freys are north of the Tumblestone. South of Red Fork sits Lord Emmon, with Ser Forley Prester and with what remains of your old host, plus the river lords who came over to us after the Red Wedding. A sullen lot, I don't mind saying. Good for sulking in their tents, but not much more. Mine own camp is between the rivers, facing the moat and Riverrun's main gates.

[Unfortunately, that won't work.] (shakes head) The Blackfish expelled all the useless mouths from Riverrun and picked this country clean. He has enough stores to keep man and horse alive for two full years.

[Our own situation is not much better.] So long as there are fish in the rivers, we won't starve, though I don't know how we're going to feed the horses. The Freys are hauling food and fodder down from the Twins, but Ser Ryman claims he does not have enough to share, so we must forage for ourselves. Half the men I send off to look for food do not return. Some are deserting. Others we find ripening under trees, with ropes about their necks.
[I doubt words will be enough, but I'll let Jaime try.] You are welcome to try, my lord, but I doubt that words will win the day. We need to storm the castle.

plots.name: Gerold Dayne
plots.description: Known as Darkstar, a knight from Starfall, dangerous and unpredictable.
plots.summary: Joins Arianne's plot, but shows signs of having his own agenda and a cruel streak that worries Arianne.

conversations.name: Gerold Dayne
conversations.thought: This plan is reckless and likely to fail, but it may serve my purposes. I'll play along for now, but I'm ready to seize any opportunity that arises. Arianne is naive if she thinks this will bring justice. Perhaps I can push events in a more interesting direction. The girl's presence opens up possibilities that Arianne hasn't considered.

utterances.message: [Their plan is foolish. There are quicker ways to start a war.] This plan of yours may not yield you what you want, princess.
[She's playing coy, but I see through her.] The Sand Snakes freed. Vengeance for Oberyn and Elia. Do I know the song? You want a little taste of lion blood.

[Justice? How naive.] Call it what you will. Crowning the Lannister girl is a hollow gesture. She will never sit the Iron Throne. Nor will you get the war you want. The lion is not so easily provoked.
[This is madness. They're all fools.] Are you blind or stupid, Oakheart? There are too many. Put up your sword.

Gerold Dayne.profile:
Gerold Dayne, known as Darkstar, is a mysterious and dangerous knight from Starfall in George R.R. Martin's "A Feast for Crows." A member of the prestigious House Dayne, he possesses a sinister reputation that sets him apart from his more honorable relatives. Darkstar joins Princess Arianne Martell's plot to crown Myrcella Baratheon as Queen of the Seven Kingdoms, though his true motivations remain obscure.

Described as unpredictable and cruel, Darkstar's presence in Arianne's conspiracy causes the princess considerable unease. His sharp wit and cynical outlook are evident in his interactions with the group, often challenging Arianne's plans and highlighting their potential flaws. When discussing the plot to crown Myrcella, he dismisses it as a "hollow gesture," demonstrating his pragmatic and possibly nihilistic worldview.

Darkstar's actions and words suggest he has his own agenda, separate from Arianne's goals of justice and vengeance for Oberyn and Elia Martell. He appears to relish the prospect of conflict, hinting at "quicker ways to start a war." This attitude, combined with his dangerous reputation, makes him a wild card in the already precarious plot.

During the confrontation with Areo Hotah that leads to the failure of Arianne's plan, Darkstar shows his pragmatic nature by urging Ser Arys Oakheart to surrender rather than fight. This moment highlights the contrast between Darkstar's survival instinct and the honor-bound actions of other characters.

Gerold Dayne's involvement in this pivotal plot thread of "A Feast for Crows" adds an element of unpredictability and danger to the already complex political machinations in Dorne. His character serves to heighten tension and introduce an air of menace to Arianne's schemes, leaving readers to wonder about his true intentions and the potential consequences of his actions.

plots.name: Hyle Hunt
plots.description: A knight who previously mocked Brienne at Highgarden.
plots.summary: Ser Hyle encounters Brienne in Maidenpool, attempting to assist her but facing rejection due to their past interactions at Highgarden.

utterances.message: [This could be significant. I must know more.] Rhaegar's rubies?

Hyle Hunt.profile:
Ser Hyle Hunt is a minor yet significant character in George R.R. Martin's "A Feast for Crows," the fourth installment of the "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. A knight of questionable repute, Hyle Hunt's past interactions with Brienne of Tarth play a crucial role in shaping their present relationship.

Hyle is first introduced as one of the men rebuilding Maidenpool under Lord Randyll Tarly's command. His history with Brienne dates back to their time at Highgarden, where he participated in mocking her, leaving a lasting negative impression. This past behavior reflects a callous side to his personality, indicative of the often cruel social dynamics in Westeros.

Despite his previous actions, Hyle attempts to assist Brienne during her search for Sansa Stark in Maidenpool. This gesture suggests a possible change in his character or, at the very least, a willingness to make amends. However, Brienne's rejection of his help underscores the lasting impact of past transgressions and the difficulty of overcoming first impressions in the world of "A Song of Ice and Fire."

Hyle's presence in Maidenpool and his association with Lord Tarly indicate his involvement in the ongoing efforts to maintain order in the war-torn Riverlands. While not a major player in the grand political schemes of Westeros, Hyle Hunt serves as a representation of the complex and often contradictory nature of knighthood in Martin's world, where honor and cruelty can coexist within the same individual.

plots.name: Ilyn Payne
plots.description: The King's Justice, a mute knight
plots.summary: Ser Ilyn is chosen by Jaime to accompany him on the mission, serving as a silent companion.

Ilyn Payne.profile:
Ser Ilyn Payne, known as the King's Justice, is a silent and enigmatic figure in the world of Westeros. A mute knight, Ilyn serves as the royal executioner, a role that has earned him both fear and notoriety throughout the Seven Kingdoms. His inability to speak, the result of having his tongue removed on the orders of the Mad King Aerys II Targaryen, adds to his ominous presence and reputation.

Physically imposing and often described as gaunt, Ilyn's appearance matches his grim occupation. His most striking feature is his silence, which makes him an ideal companion for those seeking discretion or wishing to avoid unwanted conversation. This quality leads Jaime Lannister to choose Ilyn as his companion for the mission to Riverrun, valuing the knight's inability to spread gossip or question orders.

Despite his limited role in direct plot developments, Ilyn Payne's presence serves as a constant reminder of the harsh justice and power dynamics in the world of "A Song of Ice and Fire." His unwavering loyalty to the crown and his unquestioning execution of his duties make him a reliable, if unsettling, figure in the royal court.

Throughout "A Feast for Crows," Ilyn's character remains largely unchanged, serving more as a symbol of silent authority and the ever-present threat of execution than as a dynamic personality. His inclusion in Jaime's mission to Riverrun highlights his continued importance in carrying out the will of the ruling powers, even as the political landscape of Westeros shifts dramatically around him.

utterances.message: [This girl seems genuine, but we must be thorough.] And where was Lord Baelish during this time?

Marwyn Belmore.profile:
Marwyn Belmore is a minor character in "A Feast for Crows," the fourth book in George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. As a lord of the Vale, he plays a small but notable role in the investigation of Lysa Arryn's death at the Eyrie. 

While little is known about Marwyn's physical appearance or personal history, his presence during the interrogation of key witnesses demonstrates his position of influence among the Vale nobility. Belmore appears to be a cautious and thorough individual, as evidenced by his questioning of Alayne Stone (Sansa Stark in disguise) regarding Lord Petyr Baelish's whereabouts during Lysa's demise.

Marwyn's involvement in this crucial scene highlights the political tensions and power dynamics at play in the Vale following Lysa's mysterious death. His careful probing suggests a mind attuned to the intricacies of courtly intrigue and a desire to uncover the truth behind the events at the Eyrie.

While Marwyn Belmore's character is not extensively developed in the narrative, his participation in this key investigation underscores the widespread suspicion and uncertainty surrounding Lysa Arryn's death and Petyr Baelish's subsequent rise to power as Lord Protector of the Vale.

plots.name: Osney Kettleblack
plots.description: A knight in service to Cersei, easily manipulated.
plots.summary: Osney is manipulated by Cersei into agreeing to seduce Margaery Tyrell and kill Jon Snow in exchange for rewards and a lordship.

conversations.name: Osney Kettleblack
conversations.thought: The queen's private summons both excites and unnerves me. Her attention is flattering, but I sense danger lurking beneath her words. I'm eager for advancement and rewards, yet wary of the risks involved in her schemes. I must tread carefully, balancing my ambition with self-preservation, as I navigate whatever task she has in mind for me.

utterances.message: [I'm intrigued but cautious.] I'm honored, Your Grace. What kind of task did you have in mind?
[I sense a trap but can't help being honest.] I suppose. For a girl. I'd sooner have a woman.
[Alarm bells are ringing in my head.] The little... Margaery, you mean? She's the king's wife. Wasn't there some Kingsguard who lost his head for bedding the king's wife?
[I'm both confused and aroused.] Her maidenhead, you mean?
[My ego is flattered, but I'm still uncertain.] She likes me well enough. But what happens after we... do the deed?
[I'm in too deep to back out now.] What boy?
[The prospect of reward outweighs my fear.] And then what?
[My ambition gets the better of me.] I am your man, Your Grace.

Osney Kettleblack.profile:
Osney Kettleblack is a minor yet pivotal character in "A Feast for Crows," serving as a pawn in Cersei Lannister's political machinations. A knight in service to the Lannister queen regent, Osney is characterized by his malleable nature and burning ambition, making him an ideal target for manipulation. Physically unremarkable, his most notable attributes are his susceptibility to flattery and his willingness to undertake dangerous tasks for the promise of power and pleasure.

Osney's core motivations revolve around personal advancement and the acquisition of status, as evidenced by his eagerness to accept Cersei's offer of a potential lordship. His relationship with Cersei is complex, marked by a mix of attraction, fear, and opportunism. She exploits his desires and insecurities, using her feminine wiles and promises of reward to bend him to her will.

In a crucial plot development, Cersei manipulates Osney into agreeing to seduce Margaery Tyrell, the young queen, and subsequently assassinate Jon Snow at the Wall. This scheme demonstrates Osney's significance as a tool in Cersei's efforts to eliminate perceived threats to her power. His willingness to commit adultery with the king's wife and murder showcases both his moral flexibility and the depths of his ambition.

Throughout the story, Osney's character arc is defined by his increasing entanglement in Cersei's dangerous plots, highlighting the perilous nature of court politics in Westeros. His journey serves as a cautionary tale about the risks of blind ambition and the manipulative power of those in authority.

plots.name: Shadrich
plots.description: A mysterious knight who Brienne suspects might be following her.
plots.summary: Though not directly present, Ser Shadrich's potential threat looms over Brienne, causing her to be extra cautious and prepared for a possible confrontation.

Shadrich.profile:
Ser Shadrich, also known as the Mad Mouse, is a mysterious and elusive character in "A Feast for Crows." Though he appears only briefly in the narrative, his presence casts a long shadow, particularly over Brienne of Tarth's journey. Described as a small, wiry man with a sharp wit, Shadrich is a hedge knight with ambiguous motives.

His most notable attribute is his keen interest in finding Sansa Stark, which puts him at odds with Brienne's own quest. This shared goal makes him a potential threat to Brienne, causing her to remain vigilant and wary during her travels. Shadrich's nickname, the Mad Mouse, hints at his cunning nature and perhaps unpredictable behavior.

While little is known about Shadrich's background or personal relationships, his actions suggest he is opportunistic and possibly working for his own gain. His pursuit of Sansa Stark implies he may be seeking the reward offered for her safe return, showcasing a mercenary aspect to his character.

Throughout the story, Shadrich remains a peripheral figure, more often mentioned than seen. However, his very existence adds tension to Brienne's quest, serving as a reminder of the competition and danger surrounding the search for Sansa Stark. This unseen presence contributes to the atmosphere of intrigue and uncertainty that permeates much of "A Feast for Crows."

plots.name: Talbert Serry
plots.description: Son and heir of the Lord of Southshield.
plots.summary: Talbert faces Victarion in single combat and is defeated, demonstrating Victarion's martial prowess.

conversations.name: Talbert Serry
conversations.thought: I must defend my family's honor and our lands. This ironborn brute may be strong, but I am quicker and more skilled with a blade. I'll prove myself worthy of being heir to Southshield by defeating this infamous raider. My victory here could turn the tide of this battle.

utterances.message: [I must show no fear in the face of this ironborn captain.] (raises his visor) His son and heir. Ser Talbert Serry. And who are you, kraken?
[I must strike first and fast.] (leaps to meet Victarion, swinging his longsword)
[I must find an opening in his defense.] (continues to press his attack, his longsword singing through the air)
[I can't believe he caught my sword! This can't be happening.] My sword... (falls overboard into the bloodstained waters)

Talbert Serry.profile:
Ser Talbert Serry, the son and heir of the Lord of Southshield, emerges as a minor yet significant character in "A Feast for Crows." Though his appearance is brief, it serves to highlight the martial prowess of Victarion Greyjoy and the fierce nature of the ironborn invasion of the Shield Islands.

Described as a young lord, Talbert wears rose-emblazoned armor, signifying his family's heraldry and his status as a noble of the Reach. His youth and position as heir underscore the tragic nature of his fate, representing the cost of war to noble houses.

Talbert demonstrates courage and a strong sense of duty, willingly engaging in single combat with the notorious Victarion Greyjoy to defend his family's honor and lands. His confidence in his own abilities is evident in his bold challenge to Victarion, revealing a combination of youthful bravado and genuine skill.

In combat, Talbert proves to be quick and skilled with a blade, presenting a genuine challenge to the more experienced Victarion. This suggests that he has received proper martial training befitting his status as a future lord. However, his speed and skill ultimately prove insufficient against Victarion's raw strength and battle-hardened experience.

Talbert's defeat and subsequent death at the hands of Victarion serve as a pivotal moment in the battle for the Shield Islands, demonstrating the ferocity of the ironborn invasion and the personal cost of war. His fate also emphasizes the ruthless nature of Westerosi conflicts, where even young heirs to noble houses can fall in battle.

While Talbert's role in the broader narrative is limited, his encounter with Victarion provides insight into the character of both men and the nature of the conflict between the ironborn and the mainland houses of Westeros.

plots.name: The Kindly Man
plots.description: Mentor figure at the House of Black and White, guides Arya in her training.
plots.summary: Teaches Arya about the Faceless Men's origins, instructs her to give up her possessions, and begins training her in lie detection.

plots.name: The Kindly Man
plots.description: A Faceless Man who oversees Cat's training.
plots.summary: He regularly questions Cat about what she has learned and reminds her of her duty to serve the Many-Faced God.

conversations.name: The Kindly Man
conversations.thought: Arya Stark clings too tightly to her past. She must understand that becoming a Faceless Man requires complete surrender of self. I must push her to confront this truth, to test her resolve and readiness for our ways. Will she truly give up everything, or is she not yet prepared for the path she claims to seek?

conversations.name: The Kindly Man
conversations.thought: This girl shows promise, but her past identity still lingers. I must test her thoroughly - both her ability to gather information and her progress in becoming 'no one'. Her resistance to letting go of Arya Stark concerns me. Today's questioning will reveal how far she's come and how much further she needs to go in her training.

utterances.message: [She must learn to let go of her attachments.] You need to rid yourself of all this. These things belong to Arya of House Stark. There is no place for them here.
[She still clings to her identity.] And who are you?

[She lies, but not convincingly.] A lie. Before you drink from the cold cup, you must offer up all you are to Him of Many Faces. Your body. Your soul. Yourself. If you cannot bring yourself to do that, you must leave this place.
[She misunderstands the true cost.] What we offer cannot be bought with gold. The cost is all of you.

[She is determined, but still attached to her past.] Stay, and the Many-Faced God will take your ears, your nose, your tongue. He will take your sad grey eyes that have seen so much. He will take your hands, your feet, your arms and legs, your private parts. He will take your hopes and dreams, your loves and hates. Those who enter His service must give up all that makes them who they are. Can you do that?
[She is not ready, but I will give her one more chance.] So says Arya of House Stark, eater of grave worms.
[I must assess her progress.] What do you know that you did not know when you left us?
[She's learning, but I must push her further.] It is good to know these things. And who are you?
[She's still holding onto her past. I must continue to challenge her.] You lie. You are Cat of the canals, I know you well. Go and sleep, child. On the morrow you must serve.

The Kindly Man.profile:
The Kindly Man is an enigmatic mentor figure within the House of Black and White in Braavos, playing a crucial role in Arya Stark's journey in "A Feast for Crows." As a senior member of the Faceless Men, he embodies the order's philosophy of detachment and selflessness. The Kindly Man's physical appearance is not explicitly described, emphasizing the Faceless Men's focus on shedding individual identity.

His primary function is to guide and test Arya in her training to become a Faceless Man. The Kindly Man is characterized by his calm demeanor and unwavering commitment to the order's principles. He consistently challenges Arya to abandon her past and identity, pushing her to become "No One" as required by their faith.

The Kindly Man's teaching methods are both philosophical and practical. He educates Arya about the origins of the Faceless Men and instructs her in various skills, including lie detection and the Braavosi language. His approach is often cryptic and demanding, forcing Arya to confront difficult truths about herself and the path she has chosen.

Throughout their interactions, the Kindly Man demonstrates patience but also firmness. He recognizes Arya's struggle to fully commit to the Faceless Men's ways, particularly her reluctance to give up her possessions and identity. His words often carry deeper meanings, challenging Arya to look beyond the surface and truly understand the sacrifices required of her.

The Kindly Man's role in the story serves to highlight the conflict between Arya's desire for vengeance and the Faceless Men's code of detachment. He represents the ultimate test of Arya's resolve, consistently pushing her to choose between her past and the path of the Faceless Men.

plots.name: The Waif
plots.description: Young acolyte at the House of Black and White, assists in Arya's training.
plots.summary: Helps teach Arya Braavosi and engages in the lying game with her to improve Arya's skills in detecting falsehoods.

The Waif.profile:
The Waif is a mysterious and enigmatic young acolyte at the House of Black and White in Braavos, playing a significant role in Arya Stark's journey to become a Faceless Man. Although her true name and background remain unknown, the Waif serves as both a mentor and a foil to Arya during her training.

Described as a young woman with a gaunt appearance, the Waif's physical attributes reflect the austere nature of the Faceless Men's order. Her demeanor is stern and focused, embodying the discipline required of those who serve the Many-Faced God. The Waif's primary function in the narrative is to assist in Arya's training, particularly in teaching her the Braavosi language and honing her skills in the art of deception detection.

As an integral part of Arya's education, the Waif engages in the "lying game" with her pupil, a crucial exercise designed to sharpen Arya's ability to discern truth from falsehood. This training is fundamental to the Faceless Men's craft, emphasizing the importance of perception and cunning in their secretive order.

The Waif's character serves as a constant reminder of the path Arya must follow to truly become "no one" and fully embrace the ways of the Faceless Men. Her presence challenges Arya's attachment to her past identity and pushes her towards the complete surrender of self required by their order. Despite her limited appearances, the Waif's role is pivotal in shaping Arya's character development and her struggle between maintaining her identity as a Stark and becoming a nameless assassin.

plots.name: Tommen Baratheon
plots.description: Young king of the Seven Kingdoms, son of Cersei.
plots.summary: Tommen obeys his mother's instructions, showing a meek demeanor that concerns Cersei. He asks innocent questions about the lack of people on the streets.

plots.name: Tommen Baratheon
plots.description: Young king of the Seven Kingdoms, son of Cersei.
plots.summary: Tommen attends his grandfather's wake, showing his youth and naivety while following his mother's instructions.

plots.name: Tommen Baratheon
plots.description: The young king, marrying Margaery Tyrell.
plots.summary: Tommen participates in his wedding ceremony and feast, seemingly oblivious to the political tensions surrounding him.

plots.name: Tommen Baratheon
plots.description: Young king of the Seven Kingdoms, son of Cersei.
plots.summary: Tommen desires to sit on the Iron Throne and begins jousting lessons, showing enthusiasm for knightly pursuits.

conversations.name: Tommen Baratheon
conversations.thought: I want to make Mother happy and be a good king, but I'm confused by all these rules and expectations. Why can't I ride my horse and greet the people like Uncle Jaime suggested? The rain makes everything feel sad, and I don't understand why the streets are so empty. I miss my grandfather and wonder why things are so different from when Father died.

conversations.name: Tommen Baratheon
conversations.thought: I'm frustrated with being treated like a child when I'm the king. Margaery encourages me to take charge, but Mother always resists. I want to prove I can handle royal duties like sitting on the Iron Throne. I'm nervous about confronting Mother, but determined to assert myself, even if it means disappointing her.

utterances.message: [I wish I could ride my horse like Uncle Jaime said.] Uncle Jaime said I could ride my horse and throw pennies to the smallfolk.
[The rain makes me sad.] The gods are weeping for grandfather. Lady Jocelyn says the raindrops are their tears.
[I should do as Mother says.] (closes the curtain) No, Mother.
[I'll try to sit up straight.] (sits up and adjusts his crown) No, Mother.
[The streets look empty. Is something wrong?] I thought there would be more people. When Father died, all the people came out to watch us go by.
[I'm tired of being treated like a child. I am the king, after all.] I want to sit on the Iron Throne. You always let Joff sit up there.
[She's not understanding how important this is to me.] But I'm the king. The throne belongs to me.
[I don't want to get Margaery in trouble, but I can't lie to Mother.] (His face turns red) No one told me.
[I don't want Pate to be hurt because of me.] (Mutters sullenly) No.
[I'm sorry, Margaery.] (Shuffles his feet) Lady Margaery.
[Margaery was right, I should learn to be king.] Yes. She says I have to learn to be king.
[I barely remember Lord Arryn, but I know what happened to him.] He died of a bellyache.
[I don't really want to do that, but I don't want to disappoint Mother.] Yes, Mother.

Tommen Baratheon.profile:
Tommen Baratheon, the young king of the Seven Kingdoms, ascends to the Iron Throne following the death of his brother Joffrey. As the son of Queen Regent Cersei Lannister, Tommen is a stark contrast to his cruel predecessor. Described as meek and innocent, he possesses a gentle nature that both endears him to some and concerns others, particularly his mother.

Physically, Tommen is still a child, lacking the imposing presence expected of a king. His youth is evident in his behavior and naive questions, often requiring guidance on proper royal conduct. Tommen's personality is marked by obedience and a desire to please, especially towards his mother Cersei, whose instructions he follows dutifully.

Despite his tender age, Tommen shows a growing interest in his royal duties. He expresses a desire to sit on the Iron Throne and learn the ways of kingship, influenced by his new wife, Margaery Tyrell. This budding assertion of independence creates tension with Cersei, who seeks to maintain control over both her son and the realm.

Tommen's relationships are central to his character development. His marriage to Margaery Tyrell introduces him to new perspectives on rulership, often at odds with his mother's teachings. This conflict between Margaery's encouragement and Cersei's protectiveness forms a key aspect of Tommen's character arc, as he begins to navigate the complex world of court politics.

The young king also shows an interest in knightly pursuits, enthusiastically taking up jousting lessons under Ser Loras Tyrell's guidance. This interest in chivalric activities provides a glimpse into Tommen's aspirations and the kind of king he might become if allowed to develop his own identity.

Throughout "A Feast for Crows," Tommen's character serves as a focal point for the political machinations of those around him. His innocence and malleability make him a target for influence, with various factions, including his own mother, vying to shape his reign. Tommen's journey from an obedient child to a young king struggling to assert himself forms a subtle but significant subplot in the intricate tapestry of Westerosi politics.

plots.name: Tristifer Botley
plots.description: The new Lord Botley, childhood friend of Asha.
plots.summary: Tristifer, now Lord Botley, expresses admiration for Asha. He informs her of his father's fate at the hands of Euron Greyjoy.

Tristifer Botley.profile:
Tristifer Botley is a minor yet notable character in "A Feast for Crows," the fourth book in George R.R. Martin's "A Song of Ice and Fire" series. As the newly appointed Lord Botley, Tristifer emerges as a childhood friend of Asha Greyjoy, the daughter of Balon Greyjoy and a claimant to the Seastone Chair of the Iron Islands.

Tristifer's elevation to his lordship comes under tragic circumstances, as his father was executed by Euron Greyjoy, Asha's uncle and another contender for the Iron Islands' throne. This event likely shapes Tristifer's perspective on the political turmoil engulfing his homeland.

Despite the upheaval in the Iron Islands, Tristifer maintains a strong admiration for Asha Greyjoy. Their shared history as childhood companions appears to have fostered a deep-seated affection on Tristifer's part. His expression of admiration for Asha suggests a potential romantic interest, though the extent of Asha's reciprocation is not clearly defined.

Tristifer's presence at Ten Towers on Harlaw, where he encounters Asha, indicates his involvement in the broader political machinations of the Iron Islands. As a young lord, he finds himself navigating the complex and dangerous waters of Iron Island politics, particularly in the context of the impending kingsmoot called by Aeron Damphair.

While not a central character, Tristifer Botley serves as a window into the shifting allegiances and personal relationships that underpin the power struggles in the Iron Islands. His interactions with Asha provide insight into her character and the support she might garner in her bid for leadership.

plots.name: Tywin Lannister
plots.description: The deceased Lord of Casterly Rock and former Hand of the King.
plots.summary: Tywin's corpse lies in state, symbolizing the end of an era and the challenges facing House Lannister.

Tywin Lannister.profile:
Tywin Lannister, the formidable Lord of Casterly Rock and former Hand of the King, casts a long shadow over the events of "A Feast for Crows" even in death. A cunning strategist and ruthless patriarch, Tywin's influence on the Seven Kingdoms and his own family persists beyond the grave. His corpse, lying in state at the Great Sept of Baelor, becomes a focal point for reflection and political maneuvering.

Throughout his life, Tywin was known for his unwavering dedication to the Lannister legacy, often putting family reputation above personal relationships. His complex relationships with his children – Cersei, Jaime, and Tyrion – shaped much of the series' conflict. Tywin's death, presumably at the hands of his son Tyrion, marks a turning point in the power dynamics of Westeros.

Even in death, Tywin's presence looms large. The decomposition of his body during the vigil serves as a potent symbol of the decay of Lannister power and the challenges facing the realm. His passing leaves a power vacuum that his daughter Cersei attempts to fill, seeking to appoint Jaime as Hand of the King – a move that highlights the ongoing struggle for control within the Lannister family.

Tywin Lannister's character arc, concluding with his death, represents the end of an era in Westerosi politics. His legacy of cunning, ambition, and family-first mentality continues to influence the actions of those he left behind, shaping the conflicts and power struggles that dominate "A Feast for Crows."

plots.name: Victarion Greyjoy
plots.description: Lord Captain of the Iron Fleet, brother to Balon and Euron Greyjoy.
plots.summary: Victarion arrives at Old Wyk intending to claim the throne. He grapples with his past, his loyalty to tradition, and his ambition to become king.

plots.name: Victarion Greyjoy
plots.description: The iron captain, leader of the Iron Fleet, and brother to King Euron Greyjoy.
plots.summary: Victarion leads the attack on the Shield Islands, demonstrating his prowess in battle. He struggles with his loyalty to Euron and his desire for personal glory and power.

conversations.name: Victarion Greyjoy
conversations.thought: I must secure my claim to the Seastone Chair. The Iron Islands need a strong, traditional leader, not Euron's madness or a woman's rule. My past haunts me - Euron's betrayal, my wife's infidelity, the kinslaying I was forced to commit. I'll prove my worth through strength and honor, as befits an ironborn. Asha's approach concerns me; what game is she playing?

conversations.name: Victarion Greyjoy
conversations.thought: I must prove myself as a true ironborn warrior, worthy of leading this fleet. This young lord looks eager for battle, but he'll soon learn the price of challenging the iron captain. I'll show Euron and all others that strength and steel are what truly matter, not tricks and schemes.

utterances.message: [Share the rule? With a woman? This is unexpected and confusing.] Share the rule? How could that be?
[A woman as Hand? It's unheard of. But she is Balon's daughter...] Why would you wish to be my Hand?

[She's being too soft. We are ironborn!] (chuckles) This Lady Glover plays you for a fool, niece. Sea Dragon Point and the Stony Shore are ours. Why hand back anything? Winterfell is burnt and broken, and the Young Wolf rots headless in the earth. We will have all the north, as your lord father dreamed.

[She speaks like a greenlander, not an ironborn. I must put an end to this.] Go back to your dolls, niece. Leave the winning of wars to warriors. (shows his fists) I have two hands. No man needs three.
[She thinks she has me cornered, but I have my own plans.] Hotho Humpback has offered me his daughter for my queen. If I take her, I will have the Harlaws.

[I have the upper hand now. I must press my advantage.] Rodrik has no daughters, only books. Hotho will be his heir, and I will be the king. (with growing confidence) The Crow's Eye has been too long away.
[How dare she give credit to Euron for my deeds!] (insists angrily) I burnt the lion's fleet. With mine own hands I flung the first torch onto his flagship.

[The painful memories resurface. I must control my anger.] (looks at his fists) He put a baby in her belly and made me do the killing. I would have killed him too, but Balon would have no kinslaying in his hall. He sent Euron into exile, never to return...
